metadata.sermon_title: The Enemy Lines Are Hard to Find
metadata.sermon_start_end: A friend of mine who is a child psychologist told me about something one of her young patients said. It is common practice to give toys to children in the treatment room so they work out their conflicts through play. This particular little boy was given toy soldiers [...] With the last breath of his body and the last drop of his blood he has wrought the salvation of his enemies: that is to say, the salvation of each and every one of us. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on a single pericope. It functions as a thematic speech on 'evil' and 'repentance' using a collage of texts (Psalm 19, Romans 5, Romans 11, Psalm 51, 1 Peter 3). It does not identify what is unique to one specific passage that can be found nowhere else.
quotes: In the words of our Psalm for today...
Listen to this verse from St. Paul’s letter to the Romans...
The Epistle of Peter puts it another way...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either Romans 5:6 or Romans 11:32 and derive the entire structure from that specific text's logic rather than using them as proof-texts for a general theme.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no formal exposition of the original context, the Greek text, or the historical situation of the Roman or Israelite audience. The biblical texts are treated as timeless aphorisms rather than historically situated words.
quotes: The Bible teaches us to see ourselves as God sees us.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Explain the radical nature of 'mercy upon all' in the context of Paul's argument regarding Israel and the Gentiles in Romans 9-11.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point. The application is highly concrete, referencing the Iraq war, the Taliban, the Holocaust, and Vietnam. It demonstrates a broad knowledge of the humanities (Tolkien, Solzhenitsyn, psychology).
quotes: The children in this particular news story live in the garbage dumps.
When a nation treats dissent as unpatriotic, the whole world is in trouble.
I recently read an article about repentance by Frederica Mathewes-Green...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the text's specificities rather than from the preacher's newspaper clippings.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Because there is almost no exposition, there is little to interweave. The sermon is dominated by contemporary anecdotes, with the Bible acting as a late-stage 'solution' or commentary on the human condition described.
quotes: The paradox of this is that when a Christian makes a confession of this kind... it is also liberating. We make our confessions in the secure embrace of the gospel.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Start with the text and draw the hearer into the biblical world immediately, rather than starting with a child psychologist's anecdote.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The theme of 'misery' (sin as a blurred line in the heart) is well-developed. 'Redemption' is present as the mercy of God. 'Gratitude' is less distinct, though hinted at in the 'liberating' nature of confession.
quotes: the line separating good and evil passes... right through every human heart.
God has consigned all human beings to disobedience, that he may have mercy upon all.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'gratitude' aspect by showing how this specific mercy leads to a specific new way of living.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses the 'temporal loss' of becoming a perpetrator of evil. However, it leans toward a universalism that might soften the 'narrow way.' The seriousness of the human choice is somewhat obscured by the focus on external influences (garbage dumps, vengeful fathers).
quotes: The axis of evil lies here, there, and everywhere.
Who knows if Saddam’s sons are evil? ... what influences made them evil?
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the responsibility of the individual more sharply; the 'two ways' require a decision that transcends one's 'influences'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos of the sermon, particularly in the final third. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the description of Him entering the human condition. Grace is central.
quotes: Through his Son Jesus Christ he has entered into our condition...
he died the death of one who had been declared an enemy... the salvation of each and every one of us.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Connect Christ more specifically to the 'insight' of repentance mentioned earlier, rather than as a general salvific conclusion.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1450 words, the sermon lasts about 14-15 minutes. According to Dekker's Thesis 8, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section to reach the 20-minute threshold, allowing the text to speak more fully.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon functions more as a moral-theological essay on the nature of evil and the necessity of self-reflection than as an 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage.' It lacks formal exegesis and fails the 20-minute length requirement. However, it excels in concrete contemporary application and maintains a clear focus on the 'misery' of the human heart and the 'redemption' found in Christ's mercy.
strengths: Exceptional use of humanities and contemporary culture to illustrate the human condition.
Strong psychological insight into the nature of sin and self-justification.
Clear Christocentric conclusion that emphasizes grace for the 'unrighteous'.
weaknesses: Lack of a specific biblical pericope; the Bible is used as a source of quotes rather than the foundation of the sermon.
Complete absence of original language study or historical-critical context.
Insufficient length (14.5 minutes) to achieve the 'breadth' Dekker requires.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an engaging religious speech, but according to Dekker's strict formal definition, it is not yet a sermon. It lacks the 'bicycle wheel' of rigorous exegesis and the 'breadth' of 20 minutes.
